titlestmt.subtitle: Papers of Lewis George Janes at the Lilly Library, Indiana University, Bloomington, Indiana
titlestmt.author: Electronic finding aid encoded by Indiana University Libraries.

change.item: Edits and rearrangement of content to accommodate abstract, bioghist, scopecontent, controlaccess, acqinfo, relatedmaterials, and container list. Madison Chartier
Batch update to change subject links.

did.abstract: The Janes mss., 1865-1900, consist of letters to Lewis George Janes, 1844-1901, from William Lloyd Garrison, 1805-1879; William Lloyd Garrison, Jr., 1838-1909; William James, 1842-1910; and Herbert Spencer, 1820-1903.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for research.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Lewis George Janes, 1844-1901, served as president of the Brooklyn Ethical Association from 1885-1896.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The letters in this collection are arranged as follows: Garrison, Jr. (1865, May 9); Garrison, Sr. (1866, Jan 23); William James (1891, Feb. 15); and Herbert Spencer (1890, 1891, 1897, and 1900).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Janes mss., 1865-1900, consist of letters to Lewis George Janes, 1844-1901, from William Lloyd Garrison, 1805-1879; William Lloyd Garrison, Jr., 1838-1909; William James, 1842-1910; and Herbert Spencer, 1820-1903. Many of the letters were written during the time that Janes was president of the Brooklyn Ethical Association, 1885-1896. The two Garrisons, however, writing in 1865 and 1866 respectively relate to Garrison, Sr. addressing the Union League of Rhode Island "upon our late lamented President." James writes about matters philosophical, including "the question of immortality," while Spencer's letters talk about his antagonists who continue to call him "a materialist whether you [i.e. he] like it or not," and about his poor health.

userestrict.head: Usage Restrictions
userestrict.p: Prior arrangements are not necessary before coming to the Library, however, patrons from out of town are encouraged to communicate with the Library in advance of their visits to ascertain availability of materials.
Photocopying permitted only with permission of the curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Item], Janes mss., Lilly Library, Indiana University, Bloomington, Indiana.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Writes for his father accepting the Union League of Rhode Island invitation to speak about the late President.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Thanks Janes for the additional twenty dollars voted by the Union League of Rhode Island for his lecture.
